articles.headline: Trade Fight Over Solar Benefits a Bystander
articles.snippet: A U.S. tariff ruling against China created a loophole that has benefited Taiwanese manufacturers.
articles.abstract: A U.S. tariff ruling against China created a loophole that has benefited Taiwanese manufacturers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The long-running trade conflicts over solar panels between China and the United States and Europe have sown dissatisfaction all around, leaving many manufacturers of solar materials complaining that the market is still unfair.

articles.headline: Trying to Spice a Recipe for Cinematic Popcorn
articles.snippet: The team behind “Elysium,” starring Matt Damon and Jodie Foster, promises that it has taken an imaginative detour from the familiar blockbuster formula.
articles.abstract: The team behind “Elysium,” starring Matt Damon and Jodie Foster, promises that it has taken an imaginative detour from the familiar blockbuster formula.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s been a dismal season at the box office for Hollywood blockbusters billing themselves as creative, original — anything but the standard summer sequel.

articles.headline: Inequality in America: The Data Is Sobering
articles.snippet: Despite its riches, in many areas the United States looks depressingly backward. Addressing that will take more than the president’s words.
articles.abstract: Despite its riches, in many areas the United States looks depressingly backward. Addressing that will take more than the president’s words.
articles.lead_paragraph: The good news is that President Obama appears to have decided to devote the rest of his presidency to trying to tackle the forces behind the yawning inequities that have hamstrung social and economic mobility, eroding the living standards of the middle class.

articles.headline: Lawyer Who Beat Chevron in Ecuador Faces Trial of His Own
articles.snippet: The oil company has filed a suit against Steven Donziger, who won an $18 billion case over oil spills in the Ecuadorean jungle, accusing him of manipulating evidence and bribing judges.
articles.abstract: The oil company has filed a suit against Steven Donziger, who won an $18 billion case over oil spills in the Ecuadorean jungle, accusing him of manipulating evidence and bribing judges.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steven R. Donziger — environmental hero or charlatan, depending on whom you talk to — is one of the toughest lawyers around, or slightly crazy.

articles.headline: Warrantless Cellphone Tracking Is Upheld
articles.snippet: The ruling is the first to address the constitutionality of warrantless searches of historical location data stored by cellphone service providers.
articles.abstract: The ruling is the first to address the constitutionality of warrantless searches of historical location data stored by cellphone service providers.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a significant victory for law enforcement, a federal appeals court on Tuesday said that government authorities could extract historical location data directly from telecommunications carriers without a search warrant.

articles.headline: Mugabe Keeps Grip Before Vote, but the Opposition Grows Bolder
articles.snippet: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe does not appear ready to give up power, but says that he would go if he loses Wednesday’s election.
articles.abstract: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe does not appear ready to give up power, but says that he would go if he loses Wednesday’s election.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — When the main challengers in Zimbabwe’s presidential election tried to import motorcycles to register voters across vast distances, the government impounded them, forcing the party to use bicycles instead. Then the challengers’ election chief was jailed less than a week before the vote, and denied bail the day before it.

articles.headline: Plan Aims to Enliven Paris’s Financial District, Long Called Soulless
articles.snippet: La Défense is often seen as sterile and inhospitable, but now at least three office towers are under construction there, spawning hope for a rebound.
articles.abstract: La Défense is often seen as sterile and inhospitable, but now at least three office towers are under construction there, spawning hope for a rebound.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — On Bastille Day 1989, when President François Mitterrand inaugurated the Grande Arche, a 40-story postmodern bookend about three miles to the west of the Arc de Triomphe, it seemed its own form of triumph.

articles.headline: Over a Million Are Denied Bank Accounts for Past Errors
articles.snippet: Being rejected for a bank account can lead to a succession of fees for cashing checks, paying bills and wiring money.
articles.abstract: Being rejected for a bank account can lead to a succession of fees for cashing checks, paying bills and wiring money.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mistakes like a bounced check or a small overdraft have effectively blacklisted more than a million low-income Americans from the mainstream financial system for as long as seven years as a result of little-known private databases that are used by the nation’s major banks.

articles.headline: Loner Sought a Refuge, and Ended Up in War
articles.snippet: Feeling outcast in Iraq, Bradley Manning, then a 22-year-old Army private, turned to the Internet for solace. Prosecutors called what came next one of the greatest betrayals in United States history.
articles.abstract: Feeling outcast in Iraq, Bradley Manning, then a 22-year-old Army private, turned to the Internet for solace. Prosecutors called what came next one of the greatest betrayals in United States history.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Feeling outcast and alone in Iraq, Bradley Manning, then a 22-year-old Army private, turned to the Internet for solace in early 2010, wanting to share with the world what he saw as the unconscionable horrors of war, an act that resulted in what military prosecutors called one of the greatest betrayals in the nation’s history.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Ginger Thompson

articles.headline: New Habits Transform Software
articles.snippet: An increasing focus on office collaboration is creating opportunities for software giants like Microsoft and Google and start-ups like Quip.
articles.abstract: An increasing focus on office collaboration is creating opportunities for software giants like Microsoft and Google and start-ups like Quip.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every day, millions of office workers prepare memos and reports using scissors and paste, and store data on floppy disks, though they have plenty of digital memory in their computers and the cloud. Smartphone-toting executives have their mail dumped into in-boxes, one corporate message atop another.

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Grew 1.7% During the 2nd Quarter, Topping Forecasts
articles.snippet: The Commerce Department reported that the economy, adjusted for inflation, expanded at a better-than-expected annual rate in the April-June quarter.
articles.abstract: The Commerce Department reported that the economy, adjusted for inflation, expanded at a better-than-expected annual rate in the April-June quarter.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy managed to stay on track last quarter, defying fears of another spring swoon, but doubts remain as to whether it will finally gain the kind of sustained momentum that has proved so elusive since the recovery began four years ago.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Catherine Rampell

articles.headline: Senate Panel Presses N.S.A. on Phone Logs
articles.snippet: Senators of both parties challenged the collection of records of domestic phone calls, as the latest leak provided new details on the way the agency monitors Web browsing around the world.
articles.abstract: Senators of both parties challenged the collection of records of domestic phone calls, as the latest leak provided new details on the way the agency monitors Web browsing around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senators of both parties on Wednesday sharply challenged the National Security Agency’s collection of records of all domestic phone calls, even as the latest leaked N.S.A. document provided new details on the way the agency monitors Web browsing around the world.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Chromecast, Simply and Cheaply, Flings Web Video to TVs
articles.snippet: Using Wi-Fi, the Google Chromecast makes Internet material watchable on a television for $35. Repeat, $35.
articles.abstract: Using Wi-Fi, the Google Chromecast makes Internet material watchable on a television for $35. Repeat, $35.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever hear the old saying, “Information wants to be free?” Well, here’s a corollary for you: “TV wants to be à la carte.”
